section.title: Reading Assignment
section.p: Read Section 13.3 of Applied Discrete Structures. In this section we further restrict our attention to lattices that have the algebraic properties that are required of a Boolean Algebra. Propositional logic that we saw in Chapter 3 is prime model for what Boolean Algebra is like, but there several other concrete Boolean Algebras that we will consider.

statement.p: Why can't a lattice with three elements, a mininum element, a maximum element and third element between them be a boolean algebra?

Consider the lattices of divisors of 6, 12, 16, and 30, with the partial ordering divides.
Determine which elements of D_6 have a complement.
Determine which elements of D_{12} have a complement.
Determine which elements of D_{16} have a complement.
Determine which elements of D_{30} have a complement.
Given that D_n is always a distributive lattice, for what values of n do you suppose D_n is a boolean algebra?

Recall that if [G;*] is a finite group and a \in G, the cyclic subgroup generated by a is \langle a \rangle=\{a, a*a, a*a*a, \dots\}, which is a finite set since you eventually get to the identity and can stop listing elements. For example, if the group is \mathbb{Z}_{6}, there are four different cyclic subgroups: \langle 0 \rangle, \langle 1 \rangle, \langle 2 \rangle, and \langle 3 \rangle. The other two elements of \mathbb{Z}_{6}, 4 and 5 generate subgroups that are equal to the subgroups generated by 2 and 1, respectively. The Hasse diagram for this set of subgroups with \subseteq is
List the distinct cyclic subgroups generated by elements of \mathbb{Z}_{12}. The set of subgroups you've found is a lattice with the partial ordering \subseteq. Draw the Hasse diagram for this poset.
Do the same with the cyclic subgroups generated by elements of \mathbb{Z}_{16}.
Do the same with the cyclic subgroups generated by elements of \mathbb{Z}_{30}.
Any general observations from the three cases?
